title: Who is this course for?
body:
Who is this course for?

This training course is mandatory for all employees of the Canada Border Services Agency.

title: Navigation
body:
We encourage you to complete the product in sequence because the topics are structured to build on one another. Topics in later units will make more sense after you have completed earlier units. 

Navigation Bar

Back Button

Select this button to return to the previous page.

Home Button

This button will take you to the course Home page.

Progress Bar

Displays your progress in the module and when selected you can navigate within the module.

Table of Contents

Here you will find links to useful course resources, such as:

  • Course documents
  • Learning resources
  • Course Navigation
  • Contact information
  • Glossary (if applicable)

Throughout this course, a variety of topics will be presented and different learning activities will be used to help explain the concept of Insider Threats. 

Case study

The content of this course will be presented alongside a case study of an Insider Threat, Jeffrey Delisle, a Canadian military employee who leaked top secret information.

The case study material will be identified by this symbol which is a picture of Jeffrey Delisle.

title: Course components
body:
This course will take approximately 50 minutes to complete.

Duration of the course by Module

ModuleDuration
Before you begin10 min
Module 1: Definitions and Concepts15 min
Module 2: Indicators, Factors, and Impacts of an Insider Threat15 min
Module 3: Report and mitigate an Insider Threat at the CBSA10 min
Total50 min

title: Module 2 Objectives
body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Determine the reasoning behind an employee’s decision to engage in fraudulent behaviour.
  • Recognize the indicators that someone may be an Insider Threat.
  • Identify the factors that persuade or influence someone to do something.
  • Describe the impacts of an Insider Threat.

title: Introduction
body:
Imagine if, before Delisle walked over to the Russian Embassy in 2007, one of his colleagues had noticed indicators that he might have been predisposed to becoming an Insider Threat, and had successfully reported it

Imagine what could have been saved, both for Delisle and the Royal Canadian Navy.

Now that we know the indicators of someone who might be involved as, or be predisposed to be, an Insider Threat, it is important to understand the appropriate ways that Insider Threats can be reported and mitigated.

title: The threat from inside
body:
Do you know who can become an Insider Threat?

Would you be able to identify what an Insider Threat looks like?

As we saw from the movie Betrayed, the most serious threat to many organizations, companies or governments, does not come from outside, but often comes from within.

Furthermore, there is no one single indicator that someone is an Insider Threat, but rather a combination of indicators.

title: Who can be an Insider Threat
displayTitle: Who can be an Insider Threat
body:
To understand how Jeffrey Delisle became an Insider Threat, we first need to understand who an Insider Threat is.

Who is an Insider Threat?

Insider Threats are any person with authorized access who causes harm, intentionally or otherwise, to the assets of an organization.

Organizations can often detect or control when an outsider (non-employee) tries to access company data either physically or electronically, and can mitigate the threat of an outsider stealing company property.

However, the thief who is harder to detect and who could cause the most damage is the Insider Threat – the employee with legitimate access.

That Insider Threat may steal solely for personal gain, or that Insider may be a “spy”, someone who is stealing company information or products in order to benefit another country or criminal organization.

title: CBSA’s Assets
body:
Know that because we are employees of a law enforcement agency, we have access to information that could be quite useful to others. 

We are all responsible for safeguarding the physical and informational assets of the Agency.

If these assets are compromised, there may be serious consequences on the Agency or even on a national security level.

Any person with authorized access who causes harm, intentionally or otherwise, to the assets of the CBSA is an Insider Threat.

title: How can someone become an Insider Threat?
displayTitle: How can someone become an Insider Threat?
body:
There are numerous factors that draw or push individuals to become an Insider Threat.

  • Personality traits
  • Motivations
  • Risk factors

title: Nothing in Delisle’s life seemed unusual ….
displayTitle: Nothing in Delisle’s life seemed unusual ….

title: Nothing in Delisle’s life seemed unusual ….
displayTitle: Nothing in Delisle’s life seemed unusual ….
body:
He was considered to be trustworthy and loyal to Canada when he received his security clearance to work as an intelligence operator.

He served in this capacity with 3 Intelligence Company in Halifax; a group that conducts intelligence gathering operations.

In May 1997, Delisle married Jennifer Lee Janes in Lower Sackville, Nova Scotia and they quickly expanded their family, having two girls and two boys.

title: Motivations
body:
Any number of things might motivate Insider Threats to act.

More than half spied due to divided loyalties as a sole motivator. They disagree with how their organization works and then go out and try to justify/rationalize their beliefs through information sharing with foreign entities.

Studies have shown that there are various reasons an Insider Threat may be motivated to act.

Motivators include:
instruction: Select each tab for additional information.

_items.title: Divided Loyalties
_items.body: • Allegiance to another person or company, or to a country besides Canada.

_items.title: Money, Greed, or Financial Need
_items.body:
• A belief that money can fix anything. 
  • Excessive debt or overwhelming expenses.

_items.title: Disgruntlement, Anger, Revenge
_items.body: • Disgruntlement to the point of wanting to retaliate against the organization.

_items.title: Desire for  Acceptance or Recognition
_items.body: • The Insider Threat is prepared to provide sensitive information in order to obtain that approval.

_items.title: Problems at Work
_items.body: • A lack of recognition, disagreements with co-workers or managers, dissatisfaction with the job, a pending layoff.

title: Delisle’s anti-social traits
displayTitle: Delisle’s anti-social traits
body:
Now that we have examined how someone might become an Insider Threat let’s take another look at Delisle.

How might have personality traits influenced Delisle to become an Insider Threat?

The Nova Scotia based newspaper, the Chronicle Herald, alluded to Delisle’s anti-social traits. In their article, they stated that “his characterization of this turncoat moment as ‘professional suicide’ betrays something else: a personality that puts self above all else. Surely, jeopardizing his career was the smallest of the risks involved from Day 1.”

His actions were always bound to jeopardize the security of this country, and Delisle put his personal gain above all of this.

title: Question 3
body: What are the three types of Internal Fraud?
instruction: Select the correct answer.

_items.text: a)	Asset Misappropriation; Fraudulent Statements and Reports; Corruption
b)	Asset Misappropriation; Corruption; Inappropriate Access
c)	Contracting Fraud; Fraudulent Statements and Reports; Corruption
d)	Corruption; Inappropriate Access; Fraudulent Statements and Reports

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.

The three types of internal fraud are: Asset Misappropriation; Fraudulent Statements and Reports; Corruption.

_incorrect.final: That is not correct. The answer is a) The three types of internal fraud are: Asset Misappropriation; Fraudulent Statements and Reports; Corruption.

title: Question 4
body: What personality traits may indicate that someone might be predisposed to becoming an Insider Threat?
instruction: Select all that apply.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.

Insider Threats tend to be those who present narcissist or anti-social behaviour traits. Both of which are in the continuum of personality disorders.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct. The answer is a) and c).

Insider Threats tend to be those who present narcissist or anti-social behaviour traits. Both of which are in the continuum of personality disorders.

title: Module Summary
body:
As you have learned, an Insider Threat can be anyone who causes harm to the assets of an organization. Learning what motivates an Insider Threat as well as the factors that increase the risk of an Insider Threat will better prepare you to be able to identify them within the workplace.

In the next module, we will explore the indicators that someone may be an Insider Threat and learn more about how they impact more than just their organization.

title: Indicators that someone might be an Insider Threat
displayTitle: Indicators that someone might be an Insider Threat
body:
As we saw in the Fraud Triangle, there are numerous reasons why someone may participate in fraudulent behaviour. These reasons may be turned into action, forming patterns of behaviour that we have referred to as Indicators.

There are a variety of indicators that someone may be an Insider Threat: 

  • financial indicators
  • on-duty conduct indicators
  • off-duty conduct indicators
  • personality/suspicious behaviour indicators
  • associations/travel indicators
instruction: Select each tab to reveal additional information on indicators that someone may be an Insider Threat.

_items.title: Financial
_items.body:
• Bragging about significant new purchases.
  • Carrying unusually large sums of money.
  • Receiving numerous communications from debt collectors.
  • Change in financial situation.
  • Living beyond one’s means - i.e. someone who has always complained about money problems is now wearing expensive watches, clothing, glasses, driving expensive cars, etc.

_items.title: On-duty Conduct
_items.body:
• Having unusual interest in other employees’ work or information.
  • Requesting access material or databases unrelated to the employee’s duties.
  • Seeking to obtain proprietary or classified information on subjects not related to their work duties.
  • Excessive downloading or use of photocopying equipment.
  • Making unnecessary copies of material, especially if it is proprietary or classified.
  • Without need or authorization, takes proprietary or other material home via thumb drives, computer disks, or e-mail.
  • Having repeated security violations.
  • Asking employees to run database checks for them.
  • Receiving multiple conduct complaints.
  • Submitting multiple reports of losses and/or thefts.
  • Frequently volunteering to work after regular hours or at unusual times or refusing to leave their position.

_items.title: Off-duty Conduct
_items.body:
• Having one’s driver’s license denied, suspended, restricted or revoked.
  • Demonstrating addictive behaviours.
  • Using illegal drugs or excessively consuming alcohol on a regular basis – i.e. you smell alcohol on someone’s breath after he/she returns from a break.
  • Remotely accessing the computer network while on vacation, sick leave, or at other odd times.
  • Being involved in multiple at-fault accidents or other motor vehicle violations.
  • Frequently engaging in gambling either at the casino, with friends, or online – i.e. witnessing someone gambling on his/her lunch break.

_items.title: Personality/Suspicious  Behaviour
_items.body:
• Demonstrating extreme job dissatisfaction.
  • Demonstrating emotional stress.
  • Being easily annoyed at reasonable questioning.
  • Having a change in mood.
  • Concern that they are being investigated.
  • Engaging in acts of sexual deviance or unwanted sexual behaviour.
  • Having personal life crises.

_items.title: Associations/Travel
_items.body:
• Associating with individuals who have ties to criminal organizations.
  • Engaging with suspicious personal contacts, such as with competitors, business partners or other unauthorized individuals.
  • Taking short trips to foreign countries for unexplained or strange reasons.

title: Delisle’s indicators
displayTitle: Delisle’s indicators
body:
Delisle demonstrated various indicators that predisposed him to behaviours associated with Insider Threats. 

These included:

  • Frequent voluntary work after regular hours or at unusual times
  • Unusual interest in other employees’ work or information
  • Repeated security violations
  • Extreme job dissatisfaction or emotional stress
  • Personal life crises

title: The Mosaic Effect
body:
Not only are the techniques of elicitation and cultivation used, but the “Mosaic Effect” can occur when criminal organizations or foreign entities attempt to obtain small pieces of information from numerous sources. Together, these small pieces can be compiled to give them valuable information that can compromise the physical and informational assets of an organization.

One may not think that they have offered any desired information, though when pieced together, the results can be quite valuable…creating a “Mosaic Effect”.

title: Threats & Blackmail  following inducement
body: Being threatened or blackmailed is likely to arise following any acceptance of an inducement or after having fulfilled any requested task. After accepting any form of inducement, the person on ‘the other side’ is now in a position to reveal what you have done. This puts you in a position where you may feel obligated to continue.

title: Module Knowledge Check
body: Now that you’ve covered the content in this module, let’s take a few moments to check what you’ve learned. As you go through the questions, keep in mind that marks are not assigned to the questions and the questions are not timed.

title: Question 2
body: What is an inducement?
instruction: Select the correct response from the choices below.

_items.text: a)	Something that persuades or influences someone to do something.
b)	An action intended to deceive someone.
c)	A deliberately fabricated falsehood made to masquerade as truth.
d)	An action that causes loss to another person unless a demand is met.

_feedback.correct:
Correct! 

An inducement can be something that is offered to you, or, in the case of “Personal Gain”, it is something that you decide to take for yourself as a personal benefit.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The answer is a) Something that persuades or influences someone to do something.

An inducement can be something that is offered to you, or, in the case of “Personal Gain”, it is something that you decide to take for yourself as a personal benefit.

title: Question 3
body:
To catch up on work, Mary decides to bring home some Cabinet papers that have been marked as SECRET so that she can review them in the evening. Seeing as she intends to review them at night, and then bring them back the next morning, she believes that there is no issue for concern, and that no damage can possibly be done.

This action would be an indicator that Mary may be an Insider Threat or may be vulnerable to becoming an Insider Threat.
instruction: Select True or False.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! Any deliberate violation is likely evidence of an unwillingness or inability to abide by the rules and may be a sign of anti-social traits which could predispose someone to becoming an Insider Threat.

Note: Indicators are never in isolation, they form an over-all pattern of behaviour. Indicators are also not predictors, but they do present an opportunity to intervene.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The answer is a) True.

Any deliberate violation is likely evidence of an unwillingness or inability to abide by the rules and may be a sign of anti-social traits which could predispose someone to becoming an Insider Threat.

Note: Indicators are never in isolation, they form an over-all pattern of behaviour. Indicators are also not predictors, but they do present an opportunity to intervene.

title: Module Summary
body:
After examining the indicators that someone may be an Insider Threat, and looking at other factors of persuasion that are often behind criminal activity, we examined the severe impacts of an Insider Threat on both organizations and individuals.

In the next module, we will be looking more in depth on how to minimize the risk of Insider Threats and how to report any suspected Insider Threats as an employee.

title: When you fail to report
body:
You risk both your physical security and the information security of the CBSA.

You lose the opportunity to help a co-worker resolve problems before becoming an Insider Threat or hurting others.

Disciplinary action up to and including termination and criminal and civil sanctions may result.

You cannot underestimate the role you play in protecting against Insider Threats.

You are the first line of defense.

If you see something, report it.

title: Reporting an Insider Threat with the CBSA
displayTitle: Reporting an Insider Threat with the CBSA
body:
Reporting indicators of Insider Threats plays an especially important role within an organization such as the CBSA.

It is essential that all employees understand that the CBSA’s mandate speaks to how the Agency is responsible for supporting national security and public safety through our law enforcement functions.

As such, the CBSA has more authority and discretion than many other departments/agencies and its employees are held to a higher standard.

Employees must promptly report any allegations, suspicions or information concerning Insider Threats.

In accordance with the TBS Policy on Government Security, the CBSA must ensure that their information, assets and services are safeguarded from compromise.

All employees play an important role in ensuring that the CBSA fulfills each of these fundamental obligations.

title: The Threat from Within and Your Role
Module Knowledge Check
body: Similar to the previous modules, take a few moments to check what you have learned throughout this module. As you go through the questions, keep in mind that marks are not assigned to the questions and the questions are not timed.

title: Module Summary
body:
Knowing how to report and minimize the risk of an Insider Threat can prevent harm on a widespread scale. It is your responsibility to be aware of Insider Threats within the CBSA and to report it immediately.

Early detection can minimize the damage that an Insider Threat can cause to an organization.

title: Confirm Participation
body:
Congratulations! You have completed the Insider Threat online course.

You must confirm in ESS My Learning that you have completed this course:

  1. Close this page to update your completion progress.
  2. Click the Confirm Participation link in the Confirm Participation section located at the bottom of the Course Description page.

_graphic.alt: To confirm participation, use the link in the Confirm Participation Section in My Learning.

title: Module 1 Objectives
body:
At the end of this module, learners will be able to:

  • Identify the characteristics of an Insider Threat.
  • Identify the different types of fraudulent acts that make employees susceptible to becoming an Insider Threat.
  • Recognize what motivates an Insider Threat.
  • Describe the factors that increase the risk of an Insider Threat.
  • Recall techniques used to identify an Insider Threat.

title: Module Knowledge Check
body:
Now that you’ve covered the content in this module, let’s take a few moments to check what you’ve learned. As you go through the questions, keep in mind that marks are not assigned to the questions and the questions are not timed.

If you didn’t answer a question correctly, don’t worry, we will provide you with instant feedback.      

When you’re ready, select the begin button to start.

title: Protecting Against Insider Threats
body: Because your work environment is linked to sensitive information, you play an important role in protecting against Insider Threats. As we move through the course, you will learn a number of ways to not only identify them, but also how to minimize the risk of Insider Threats.

title: Jeffrey Delisle - the beginning ….
displayTitle: Jeffrey Delisle - the beginning ….
body:
To understand how Jeffrey Delisle became a “spy” or “Insider Threat”, we must look back on the events in his life that shaped his ultimate decision to walk into the Russian embassy and share Canadian military secrets with the Russians.

Jeffrey Paul Delisle was born March 30, 1971, and raised in Lower Sackville, Nova Scotia.

He graduated from Sackville High School in June 1990. A friend described him as the “sort of person who just blended into the background".

He joined the Canadian Forces as a reservist in January 1996.

title: Impacts of Delisle’s case
displayTitle: Impacts of Delisle’s case
body:
Not surprisingly, Insider Threats can be catastrophic for organizations and for individuals alike. Some cases impact not only organizations and individuals, but can have national and global ramifications. Let’s consider how the Jeffrey Delisle case impacted Canada.

About the Delisle case, the National Post stated “Delisle’s unauthorized disclosure to the Russians since 2007 has caused severe and irreparable damage to Canadian interests.”

His actions jeopardized national security as well as the relationship of trust we enjoy with our closest allies.

title: Question 1
body: Insider Threats are any person with authorized access who causes harm, intentionally or otherwise, to the assets of an organization.
instruction: Select the correct answer.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Insider Threats are any person with authorized access who causes harm, intentionally or otherwise, to the assets of an organization.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

Insider Threats tend to be people with narcissistic or anti-social traits. Both of these aspects are part of the continuum of personality disorders.

title: Delisle’s timeline of indicators
displayTitle: Delisle’s timeline of indicators
instruction: Select the pins beside each year to view the events.

_items.body: In February 1998, less than one year after the wedding, he filed for personal bankruptcy declaring liabilities of $18,587 and assets of $1,000.

In March 2001, Delisle left the reserves and enrolled as a regular member of the Canadian Forces. By October 2001, he successfully completed a leadership course and became a Corporal. Around this time, according to former neighbours, the Delisles moved into a co-op for low-to-moderate income households in Lower Sackville

In 2004, his young daughter was hospitalized after being hit by a vehicle just one block away from their home. For years following this event, Delisle pursued the offending driver for money – without success.

In November 2006, Delisle was promoted to Sergeant but his naval career never got off the ground since his diabetes prevented him from deploying as a sailor. That same year, he began working at the Chief of Defence Intelligence Office in Ottawa.

When he moved to Ottawa for the Strategic Joint Staff Division in 2007, the Delisle family took up residence in a nearby suburb and a former neighbour recalled seeing Delisle hiding behind a hedge to see what his wife was doing at the home of another man in the neighbourhood. This was the same year he began to voluntarily share secret information with the Russian embassy.
By 2008, Delisle suffered from extreme job dissatisfaction. In an effort to advance his career, he enrolled in the faculty of arts at the Royal Military College in Kingston, majoring in politics.
Despite graduating from Royal Military College with a Bachelor of Arts in 2010, Delisle never felt that his career had reached its full potential.

In August 2011, he was posted to the HMCS Trinity multinational naval intelligence and communications centre in Halifax. The centre is a multinational base with access to secret data from NATO countries which tracks vessels entering and exiting Canadian waters via satellites, drones and underwater devices. Delisle's top secret security clearance had lapsed before he had been transferred to Trinity in August 2011. The transfer came after Delisle was promoted to an officer, giving him access to even more classified material.

title: Delisle’s timeline of factors
displayTitle: Delisle’s timeline of factors
body: Take a look at how Delisle demonstrated clear indicators of an Insider Threat.
instruction: Select each pin to reveal information about Delisle's activities.

_graphic.alt: Timeline of Delisle's activities from 2007 to 2010.

_items.body:
Repeated Security violations:

In July 2007, Delisle walked into the Russian Embassy in Ottawa and offered to sell secrets to that country's military intelligence agency (GRU). He entered the Russian embassy the day he discovered his wife was having an affair. As he described it, "that was the end of my days as Jeff Delisle".

At the time, Delisle was working on a network called STONEGHOST. This network is used for information sharing and exchange between the five eyes countries: United States, Britain, Australia, New Zealand and Canada. Using a thumb drive, he would download intelligence data from the system and hide the drive somewhere on his body when leaving the secure area later passing it over to the Russians.

Extreme job dissatisfaction:
By 2008, Delisle suffered from extreme job dissatisfaction. In an effort to advance his career, he enrolled in the faculty of arts at the Royal Military College in Kingston, majoring in politics. This was part of a university training plan for non-commissioned members of the Canadian Forces. Although he received his commission as a Sub-Lieutenant, he believed that his inability to be deployed as a sailor due to his diabetes had severely stunted his career. 

Personal life crises (including emotional stress due to marriage breakdown and financial crises):
Delisle and his wife did not have a perfect marriage, actually, it was far from it. When interviewed by the CBC Fifth Estate, Delisle’s now ex-wife stated “Our marriage wasn't very good. A lot of it stemmed from computer using. He played a lot of games…. for a very long time. So he lived in his own little world”. In June 2008, Delisle and his wife signed a separation agreement, which stipulated that Delisle would assume the couple’s debts on three credit cards and a consolidated loan.
By 2009, he owed thousands of dollars on a government American Express card.
On May 3, 2010, Delisle and his wife filed for divorce.

title: The Mosaic Effect in CBSA
body: Because you work in a law enforcement agency, you carry valuable information (however small), some of which can be used against the CBSA if taken in another circumstance.
instruction: Select each piece to see how the Mosaic Effect could begin to take place within the CBSA.

_items.title: Employee A
_items.body: Employee A is a BSO at a small port of entry. Last week he went for drinks with his colleagues at the local pub. Joking around about how he can never remember his logon password, he says “I just use my home address, easy to remember!”

_items.title: Employee B
_items.body: Employee B works in enforcement and intelligence and often works on high profile cases. After a long day at work, she posts on Facebook that she is increasingly frustrated with her workplace and manager.

_items.title: Employee C
_items.body: Employee C works for the Human Resources Branch. She received a phone call from an employee claiming to work for the CBSA requesting an organizational chart of the HQ Security Managers. She complies and reads off the names and numbers of the Management team.

title: Types of Inducements
body: Any one of these could be attractive to an individual on the edge of becoming an Insider Threat.
instruction: Select the pins for a description.

_items.title: Lifestyle
_items.body:
• Cars/boats
  • Jewellery
  • Vacations
  • Property
  • Clothing
  • Entertainment

_items.title: Personal Gain
_items.body:
Information:

  • For yourself
  • To benefit a family member or friend

_items.title: Financial
_items.body:
• Cash
  • Loans
  • Alleviation of debt

_items.title: Hospitality
_items.body:
• Meals
  • Tickets
  • Cultural
  • Sponsorship

title: Impacts of an Insider Threat on the CBSA
displayTitle: Impacts of an Insider Threat on the CBSA
body: Let’s take a look at a few cases to see just how much an Insider Threat jeopardizes operations here within the CBSA.
instruction: Select a photo to read the individual's biography.

_items.title: Marilyn Béliveau
_items.body:
Béliveau was hired at Canada Customs while in her early 20s, in January 2003. Soon after, she had maxed out her credit card on lavish purchases. She had a boyfriend who was a drug dealer, and continually associated with old high school friends that were involved in dealing drugs.

Through these high school friends, she became involved in a larger network of organized crime. In return for money/gifts, she assisted gang members in getting ephedrine shipped into Canada for the purposes of making crystal meth.

She ensured that certain shipping containers were able to bypass inspections at the border by using CBSA databases to warn her friends when shipments were about to be searched.

She was arrested as a result of the efforts of Project Colisée (a major investigation into the Mafia in Montréal).

Béliveau was sentenced to two years minus one day to be served in the community and three years’ probation in February 2013.

_items.title: Jasbir Singh Grewal
_items.body:
Grewal was recruited by an ex-RCMP officer to allow vehicles containing cocaine to pass through his primary inspection lane at the Lynden/Aldergrove Port of Entry.

Grewal would be informed by telephone that a recreational vehicle containing cocaine was soon to approach the international border crossing. The driver of the recreational vehicle was told to approach the crossing at a specific booth that was staffed by Jasbir Singh Grewal. The driver complied with his instruction and Jasbir Singh Grewal knowingly passed the vehicle containing the cocaine.

Grewal would purposely fail to document the border crossings each time the recreational vehicle containing cocaine passed into Canada. He did so to avoid detection by law enforcement to his and his conspirator’s illegal activities.

In exchange for the vehicle to pass undetected, Grewal was paid up to $50,000.

In 2011, Grewal was sentenced to five years in a United States jail, followed by four years of supervised release.

_items.title: Baljinder Kandola
_items.body:
A BSO in PAC region, facilitated the illegal importation of cocaine and firearms into Canada. 
When a vehicle arrived at his Primary Inspection Line, Kandola purposely failed to properly process the individuals (names and license plates), and subsequently allowed them to enter the country.

The "transporter" was carrying 208 kilos of cocaine and three guns. Kandola received approximately $10,000 for turning a blind-eye.

Police on both sides of the border had been investigating the smuggling operation for months and had surveillance video and intercepted calls and conversations that made up much of the evidence at trial.

Kandola was sentenced in 2012 to 15 years in jail.

_graphic.alt: Blank silhouette of a male individual

_items.title: Nancy Cedeno
_items.body:
After joining the CBSA in 2003, Cedeno was recruited by organized crime to take part in a drug smuggling operation in 2005. 

The BSO provided individuals with daily security codes that are used by customs officials to decide which bags would be searched at the security gates at the Montréal airport. 

By purchasing these codes, members of organized crime were well-suited to smuggle cocaine into the country. 

Cedeno was arrested at Montréal’s main airport in 2006 as part of Operation Colisée.

Cedeno was found guilty of corruption in 2009 and for accepting money in exchange for providing drug dealers with confidential information on bag searching procedures. She received a two-year suspended sentence and one year under ‘evening house arrest’.

_items.title: James Munro
_items.body:
James Munro, a 26-year-old BSO, worked at Quebec's Lacolle border crossing.

Munro was involved with a criminal network that was responsible for bringing 25,000 ecstasy pills into the United States as part of a deal made with an undercover FBI agent.

Munro’s criminal counterparts relied on his ability to facilitate the smuggling of illegal narcotics in and outside of Canada.

In 2009, Munro was sentenced to eight years in prison by Judge Richard Marleau, in Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu, Court of Québec.

_items.title: Chad Gale
_items.body:
Gale intentionally allowed individuals to come into Canada (in large rental trucks) for the purposes of smuggling tobacco.

In order to conceal an individual’s identity, Gale intentionally misused the CBSA databases to conceal their identity. He purposely modified names and dates of birth; as well as turning off the system. He carried out these acts for six individuals on more than 20 occasions.

Gale was arrested in December 2016 following an investigation by both Canadian and American agencies. He was convicted on one count of breach of trust, and received a sentence of two years’ probation and 150 hours community service.

title: Purpose of this course
body:
Mole. Spy. Espionage.

These are all terms which the CBSA refers to as an Insider Threat.

Thanks to pop culture, our minds conjure silhouettes of shady figures lurking in dark corners, but Insider Threats occurring within the security organizations of today are much more discreet.

The purpose of this course is to explain what an Insider Threat is and what you can do as an employee to minimize the presence and impact of Insider Threats within CBSA.

title: A Spy …An Insider Threat …
displayTitle: A Spy …An Insider Threat …
body:
The details of Jeffrey Delisle becoming a ‘spy’ or an ‘Insider Threat’ against the Canadian government showcases many of the typical characteristics that will be discussed in this section. As you move forward, we will work through the Jeffrey Delisle case, provide his real life examples and try to facilitate an understanding of the realities faced in our workplace today.

Perhaps you know of others who:

  • have compromised protected or classified information,
  • posed a threat to their organizations, and
  • placed national security at risk?

title: How does fraud relate to Insider Threats?
displayTitle: How does fraud relate to Insider Threats?
body:
To understand what an Insider Threat is we must also understand what deliberate fraud is and how it takes place in the workplace.

Employees engaging in fraudulent behaviour in the workplace can be considered a deliberate security threat.

title: Narcissitic and Anti-Social Traits
body:
Both types of people violate the rules, but each for different reasons. 

  • Narcissists accept the rules, but feel that they don’t apply to them. 
  • Anti-socials reject the rules entirely.

title: Question 2
body: Studies have shown that ____ critical factors normally have to exist before a previously trustworthy and loyal employee commits an Insider Threat act.
instruction: Select the choice from the list below that can be used to fill in the blank.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Studies have shown that three critical factors normally have to exist before a previously trustworthy and loyal employee commits an Insider Threat act.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The answer is c) Three.

Studies have shown that three critical factors normally have to exist before a previously trustworthy and loyal employee commits an Insider Threat act.

title: Introduction
body:
There are a number of indicators that someone may be an Insider Threat or may be vulnerable to becoming an Insider Threat. As we examine the numerous indicators of someone who may be predisposed to be an Insider Threat, keep in mind that:

  • Indicators are never in isolation, they form an overall pattern of behaviour.
  • Indicators are not predictors, but they do present an opportunity to intervene.

title: Fraud Triangle
body:
The reasons why someone might engage in fraudulent behaviour can be complex and difficult to discern.

A useful way to look at why someone might become an Insider Threat and what are indicators of that behaviour is through the Fraud Triangle.

The Fraud Triangle is a way of conceptualizing the reasoning behind an individual’s decision to commit internal fraud.
instruction: Select each pin of the triangle to understand different ways an individual might turn to fraudulent behaviour and become an Insider Threat.

_items.title: Opportunity
_items.body:
The belief that an act of fraud can be committed and remain undetected

  • Using one’s position and authority as a means for engaging in fraudulent activity.
  • Capitalizing on lack of monitoring/oversight.
  • Using one’s ability to deceive using minimal effort.

_graphic.alt: Fraud Triangle equally divided into three sections; opportunity, pressure, and rationalization.

_items.title: Pressure
_items.body:
The need that an individual attempts to satisfy by committing fraud

  • Expensive medical bills
  • Expensive tastes
  • Addiction problems
  • Living beyond one's means
  • High personal debt or credit
  • Substantial financial losses
  • Undue pressure to succeed
  • Greed
  • A feeling of entitlement

_graphic.alt: Fraud Triangle equally divided into three sections; opportunity, pressure, and rationalization.

_items.title: Rationalization
_items.body:
The ability to justify the fraudulent act

  • “I do not care”
  • “I am just borrowing the money”
  • “Everybody does it”
  • “I am not hurting anyone”
  • “It is for a good cause”
  • “It is not really a serious matter”
  • “The organization can afford it”
  • “I deserve it”

_graphic.alt: Fraud Triangle equally divided into three sections; opportunity, pressure, and rationalization.

title: How is someone recruited to become an Insider Threat?
displayTitle: How is someone recruited to become an Insider Threat?
body:
As someone working for the Government of Canada, you have access to classified/privileged information that may be attractive to people involved in criminal activities, or foreign intelligence that need to or would like to advance their own foreign policy, security, commercial/economic interests.

Two of the more common methods that are used by foreign entities or criminal organizations to gather information are:

  • Elicitation
  • Cultivation
instruction: Select each tab for more information on the two methods.

_items.title: Elicitation
_items.body:
Elicitation is a technique that is used to engage you in what appears to be harmless or random conversation, but the aim is to subtly extract information about yourself, your work and/or your colleagues.

  • Quick conversation(s)
  • Appears to be harmless
  • Appears to be random
  • Seems innocent

Warning signs include:

  • Appealing to your ego through flattery
  • Using false statements to get you to correct them
  • Volunteering information (the “give to get” trick) – in hopes that you provide information in return
  • Leading you to believe that they are knowledgeable about your area of expertise

_items.title: Cultivation
_items.body:
Contrary to elicitation, which usually takes place through quick conversation, cultivation includes a more well-orchestrated approach.

It involves a relationship established between the representative and the person being recruited.

Avoiding any kind of elicitation or cultivation involves vigilance and carefully monitoring your relationships, especially new ones. Always be mindful of discussions regarding your work, even if seemingly benign.

title: What is an inducement?
body:
The last recruitment technique we will examine, and one of the most effective, are inducements.

Basically, an inducement is something that persuades or influences someone to do something.

It can be something that is offered to you, or, in the case of “Personal Gain”, it is something that you decide to take for yourself as a personal benefit.

title: Impacts of an Insider Threat
body:
Now that we’ve learned more in depth about the indicators of Insider Threats, and about how actions can often be followed by dangerous activity such as threats or blackmail. Let’s take a closer look at the impacts across the board.

Insider Threats can have grievous impacts on both organizations and individuals.
instruction: Select each arrow to read more about the consequences of an Insider Threat.

_items.title: Impact on the Canada Border Services Agency
_items.body: Insider Threats tarnish the reputation of the Agency and the individuals involved, and, most importantly, jeopardize the security of our country by making it more difficult to prevent criminal activity.

_graphic.alt: icons of people connected to represent an organization

_items.strapline: Impact on the Canada Border Services Agency

_items.title: Impact on individuals
_items.body:
The actions of an Insider Threat can have a negative impact not only on themselves and the individuals they have worked with but also with their family and friends.

  • Reputations destroyed
  • Relationships ruined
  • Trust damaged

_graphic.alt: woman sitting at a computer looking upset

title: Module 3 Objectives
body:
After completing this module, learners will be able to:

  • Describe why it is important to report all allegations, suspicions or information concerning misconduct (including Insider Threats).
  • Explain how Insider Threats and fraudulent acts are detected.
  • Recognize the avenues for reporting Insider Threats.
  • List additional methods that CBSA employees can use to mitigate Insider Threats.

title: Obligation to Report
body:
CBSA employees are held to a higher standard given the nature of their work. It is your obligation to report any Insider Threats and/or if you have personally been approached to engage in any illegal activities that would encourage you to act as an Insider Threat.

This is consistent with your obligation under the CBSA Code of Conduct to promptly report any allegation, suspicion or information concerning employee misconduct.

Unfortunately, Insider Threats often go unreported until it is too late. In the majority of past cases, relevant information was available, yet went unreported.

How different might things have been had someone said something.

title: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA)
body:
While it is mandatory to report serious misconduct CBSA’s Code of Conduct, it is voluntary to disclose allegations of wrongdoing, under the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA).

Under section 8 of the PSDPA, wrongdoing is defined as:

  • a contravention of any Act of Parliament or of the legislature of a province, or of any regulations made under any such Act, other than a contravention of section 19 of this Act
  • a misuse of public funds or a public asset
  • a gross mismanagement in the public sector
  • an act or omission that creates a substantial and specific danger to the life, health or safety of persons, or to the environment, other than a danger that is inherent in the performance of the duties or functions of a public servant
  • a serious breach of a code of conduct established under section 5 or 6
  • knowingly directing or counselling a person to commit a wrongdoing set out in any of paragraphs (a) to (e)

If employees are in possession of information that could demonstrate that a wrongdoing has been, or is about to be committed, they may seek advice from the Senior Officer for Internal Disclosure (SOID) to determine if a disclosure is warranted.

A disclosure of wrongdoing can be made internally or externally.

Internal mechanisms for the disclosure of wrongdoing are:

  • the SOID; and
  • supervisor/manager.

The Public Sector Integrity Commissioner (PSIC) is external to the Agency. In addition to receiving disclosures of wrongdoing, PSIC has the exclusive authority to deal with complaints of reprisal.

title: Methods to minimize the risk of an Insider Threat
displayTitle: Methods to minimize the risk of an Insider Threat
body:
Understanding your reporting obligations as identified in the CBSA Code of Conduct is very important. However, you should be aware of some of the additional strategies that you can use to help mitigate Insider Threat within the Agency.

As employees of the CBSA, methods you should use to mitigate the risks of Insider Threats include the following.
instruction: Select the tabs to reveal information about each method.

_items.title: Method 1
_items.body:
Method 1- Reviewing CBSA’s Security Volumes

  • Comprises the full suite of policies, directives, and procedures for all areas of security at the CBSA.
  • Applies to all CBSA Branches at Headquarters (HQ) and the Regions, all CBSA employees (permanent, term, casual, and part-time), contract and private agency personnel, and to individuals seconded or assigned to the CBSA, including students.
  • Can be accessed through Atlas.

_items.title: Method 2
_items.body:
Method 2 - Participating in Security Training Courses

These tools are available in order for you to increase your security awareness and knowledge in order to protect information, assets and employees.​​​​​​​

_items.title: Method 3
_items.body:
Method 3 - Understanding how the Employee Assistance Program (EAP) can help

The EAP promotes wellness through intervention, promotion and prevention. It's a completely confidential and free service that is accessible to all employees and their dependents 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. EAP can be helpful when issues arise as a result of professional or personal stressors. Research has shown that EAP is a valuable tool that contributes to lowering Insider Threat risks.

title: Question 2
body:
While it is mandatory to report serious misconduct, under the CBSA Code of Conduct, it is voluntary to disclose allegations of wrongdoing, under the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA).

If a CBSA employee was aware of an Insider Threat, they are under no obligation to report it.
instruction: Select True or False.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

While it is mandatory to report serious misconduct CBSA’s Code of Conduct, it is voluntary to disclose allegations of wrongdoing, under the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA).

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The answer is True.

While it is mandatory to report serious misconduct CBSA’s Code of Conduct, it is voluntary to disclose allegations of wrongdoing, under the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA).

title: Course Summary
body:
This course provided you with the knowledge of what an Insider Threat is and how to minimize the presence of Insider Threats within the CBSA.

After taking this course you should able to:

  • Detect and explain Insider Threats
  • Identify the different types of internal fraud that can occur
  • Employ mitigating strategies to minimize the risk of an Insider Threat
  • Report any suspicion, knowledge or information on an Insider Threat

Remember, it is both your responsibility and an obligation to report any suspected Insider Threat activity immediately.

title: Scenario
body:
When Jane graduated from the CBSA’s Officer Induction Training Program (OITP) in 2017, the 30 year old considered it to be one of the proudest days of her life. She was pleased to have found a career that offered her job security, good wages, excellent benefits, and exciting opportunities.

When off-duty, Jane spent most of her spare time either shopping or frequenting nightclubs. Her colleagues often complimented her on her large, expensive wardrobe. Although she was earning a good wage, it did not allow her to maintain her preferred lifestyle, and she began to accumulate a substantial amount of credit card debt. 

Since joining the CBSA, Jane found herself becoming close with a number of acquaintances that she once knew from high school, and hasn’t had any contact with in many years. As she spent more time with these individuals, Jane became aware that some of them may have had connections with organized crime in the city that she lived in; however, since Jane only occasionally associated with these individuals, she did not see the need to disclose this to her supervisor. In addition, Jane’s new boyfriend, was also a known drug dealer in the past.

In 2020, Jane found herself becoming particularly close to one of her old high school friends named Marcus. Marcus had begun to show a keen interest in Jane’s new profession and they spent many hours reminiscing about their high school days as well as discussing the inner workings of CBSA. Initially, Marcus questioned Jane about seemingly harmless things like which border crossings were short staffed and what were the peak times for examinations at a particular crossing. Marcus would often spoil her by buying her gifts and treating her friends to drinks at a local night club (which was known to be frequented by members of organized crime). 

On one occasion, Jane showed up at the night club and her friends were using cocaine openly at the V.I.P table. When it was her turn, Jane declined. Since she did not try the cocaine, she did not think it would impact her career with the CBSA. 

In 2021, Jane’s credit card debt began to mount. Jane turned to Marcus for some financial advice – since he currently owned a lucrative shipping company. Jane advised Marcus that she was contemplating declaring bankruptcy but was concerned about the potential damage to her reputation. Marcus shared her concerns and offered to return in a few days with a better solution to her financial woes.  

Later that week, Marcus advised Jane that he had the solution to all of her problems. She could earn a substantial amount of money by simply ensuring that the shipping containers from his company were able to bypass inspections at the border. He told her that this would enable his company to have quicker delivery times, and would indirectly result in cost-savings for him. Since she had the authority to clear containers through customs, Marcus felt that this was a simple solution. As time went on, Jane used the information found in the CBSA databases to warn Marcus when his shipments were about to be searched, and eventually provided him with instructions for concealing drug shipments. Marcus always ensured that she was handsomely rewarded for the information that she provided.

title: Question 1
body: Identify an example of an indicator that Jane was displaying, which could have indicated a vulnerability to her becoming an Insider Threat?
instruction: Select the correct response.

_items.text: a)	Employment Tenure: Jane being a relatively new employee
b)	Financial: Excessive spending habits/financial troubles
c)	Associations: Associating with individuals who are engaged in criminal activities

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Excessive spending habits/financial troubles and engaging with individuals who are engaged in criminal activities are types of indicators that somebody might be susceptible to becoming an Insider Threat.

Remember, indicators should not be considered in isolation and they are not predictors; however, they do present an opportunity for intervention.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The correct answer is d).

Excessive spending habits/financial troubles and engaging with individuals who are engaged in criminal activities are types of indicators that somebody might be susceptible to becoming an Insider Threat.

Remember, indicators should not be considered in isolation and they are not predictors; however, they do present an opportunity for intervention.

title: Question 2
body: If you were a colleague of Jane’s, and you witnessed (or became aware of) some of her actions, what would you do?
instruction: Select the correct response.

_items.text: a)	Talk to Jane about my concerns.
c)	Bring my concerns to my direct manager/supervisor.
d)	Not tell anybody, as I would not want to offend Jane, or infringe on her privacy.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

You have an obligation under the CBSA Code of Conduct to promptly report any allegation, suspicion or information concerning employee Misconduct to your: Immediate supervisor or manager; or Director (if the circumstances warrant it).

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

You have an obligation under the CBSA Code of Conduct to promptly report any allegation, suspicion or information concerning employee Misconduct to your: Immediate supervisor or manager; or Director (if the circumstances warrant it).

title: Question 3
body: What could Jane have done to handle her situation in a more appropriate manner?
instruction: Select all that apply.

_items.text: a) Be truthful about her associations when joining the Agency.
c) Ensure that she is familiar with the Agency’s security policies.
d) Talk with her manager/supervisor in regard to her situation.
e) Ensure that she has taken the mandatory online security courses (offered by the CBSA).

title: Question 5
body: What types of inducements did Jane receive from Marcus?
instruction: Type your response and select submit.

_answers: Receiving drinks at a nightclub/restaurant friends to drinks at a local night club

_feedback.correct:
The following are the types of inducements that Jane received from Marcus:

  • Receiving gifts
  • Receiving drinks at a nightclub/restaurant friends to drinks at a local night club
  • Receiving (being offered) illicit drugs (cocaine)
  • Receiving money/cash

_incorrect.final:
The following are the types of inducements that Jane received from Marcus:

  • Receiving gifts
  • Receiving drinks at a nightclub/restaurant friends to drinks at a local night club
  • Receiving (being offered) illicit drugs (cocaine)
  • Receiving money/cash

title: Question 4
body: What type of Internal Fraud was Jane engaging in?
instruction: Select the correct response.

_feedback.correct:
Correct.

Asset Misappropriation and Corruption involves the damage, theft or misuse of CBSA assets (this includes the misuse of a CBSA electronic database).

Corruption involves dishonest or unethical conduct (bribery, facilitation, conflict of interest) by a person entrusted with a position of authority, often to acquire personal benefit.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The answer is d).

Asset Misappropriation and Corruption involves the damage, theft or misuse of CBSA assets (this includes the misuse of a CBSA electronic database).

Corruption involves dishonest or unethical conduct (bribery, facilitation, conflict of interest) by a person entrusted with a position of authority, often to acquire personal benefit.

title: Question 6
body: What would be the impact of Jane’s action on the CBSA?
instruction: Type your response and select submit.

_answers: Jane’s actions would have tarnished the reputation and trust of the Agency; as well as jeopardize the security of our country by facilitating criminal activity.
In addition, Jane’s actions would have also negatively impacted the individuals that she worked with, her family and friends.

_feedback.correct:
Jane’s actions would have tarnished the reputation and trust of the Agency; as well as jeopardize the security of our country by facilitating criminal activity.

In addition, Jane’s actions would have also negatively impacted the individuals that she worked with, her family and friends.

_incorrect.final:
Jane’s actions would have tarnished the reputation and trust of the Agency; as well as jeopardize the security of our country by facilitating criminal activity.

In addition, Jane’s actions would have also negatively impacted the individuals that she worked with, her family and friends.

title: Delisle’s motivations
displayTitle: Delisle’s motivations
body:
Are there any factors or characteristics of Jeffrey Delisle’s life that you’ve seen so far that may have motivated him to become an Insider Threat? 

Let’s compare information from studies done on the motivations of an Insider Threat with what we know from Delisle’s timeline:
instruction: Select the arrows for more information

_items.title: What we know:
_items.body:
Usually the last act of a long-simmering emotional and/or personal crisis.

Delisle experienced a number of life-altering and traumatic events over the decade.

_graphic.alt: Man with an umbrella and a cloud pouring rain

_items.title: What we know:
_items.body:
A majority volunteered their services to a foreign government. They were not enticed, persuaded, manipulated, or coerced.

Delisle required no external persuasion to volunteer information to the Russian embassy.

_items.title: What we know:
_items.body:
Almost all were trustworthy and loyal when first given a security clearance.

Delisle had a long career in security.

_items.title: What we know:
_items.body:
They changed over a period of time.

His loyalty became divided while emotionally charged events where occurring in his life and he experienced job dissatisfaction.

_graphic.alt: Man sitting on a graph that is pointing downwards

_items.title: What we know:
_items.body:
A security concern can arise when a person’s view of their own abilities or importance is so grossly out of line with reality that they are destined for disappointment, rather than success.
They may be unable to accept criticism or failure. Individuals may seek out some other source for validation and affirmation of their self-perceived abilities. In some cases, they have turned to a foreign intelligence service to fulfill their emotional needs.

We will never fully know what was inside Delisle’s mind the day he walked into the Russian embassy, but we do know he said “the day I flipped sides … from that day on, that was the end of my days as Jeff Delisle.”

_graphic.alt: Business man at a crossroads wondering what to do

title: The Mosaic Effect in CBSA?
body: Although seemingly benign information, together, these three employees provide examples of what could be “starting point” information that criminal organizations or foreign entities could use to start digging for more information.

title: Question 1
body: What are the three pieces of the triangle that help understand different ways an individual might turn to fraudulent behaviour and become an Insider Threat?
instruction: Select the correct answer.

_items.text: d)	Personal Gain, Opportunity, Financial Problems

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. The correct answer is b). Pressure, Opportunity, Rationalization.

title: What are the different types of fraud?
displayTitle: What are the different types of fraud?
body:
According to the Association of Certified Fraud Examiners (ACFE), there are three types of internal fraud:

  • Asset Misappropriation
  • Fraudulent Statements and Reports
  • Corruption
instruction: Select each box or arrow “>” to read the definition of each type of fraud.

_items.title: Asset Misappropriation
_items.body:
Damage, theft or misuse of CBSA assets (physical or information) constitutes as Asset Misappropriation.

  • Government Property
  • Information
  • Other Assets

“Asset Misappropriation” can be thought of as a theft of something of value that belongs to the organization.

Generally, high-value assets that are easy to transport and to dispose of are at highest risk.

Government Property

  • Behaviour that leads to damage of Government property
  • Inappropriate use of office supplies, phones, stamps, etc.
  • Stealing of Government property
  • Using a Government vehicle or facility for non-work purposes
  • Conducting personal business/activity while on duty
  • Failure to report lost, stolen or damaged Government property

Information

  • Inappropriate use/access/disclosure of classified, protected or sensitive CBSA information
  • Misuse of user name and/or password as login credential
  • Unauthorized/inappropriate alteration/modification of CBSA documentation or information

Other Assets

  • Misuse of an individual designated travel card (IDTC)
  • Improper or careless use of an individual designated travel card (IDTC)
  • Improper use of acquisition card, including vehicle fuel card
  • Improper use of job title, CBSA badge or any other official identification
  • Improper use or falsification of taxi chits
  • Failure to account and report for assets lost, stolen or damaged (e.g. loss of duty firearm ammunition)

_items.title: Fraudulent Statements and Reports
_items.body:
The falsification or destruction of financial or non-financial reports/statements/documents in order to obtain some form of improper gain or benefit.

  • Attendance – Time –Hours
  • Falsification of documentation

“Fraudulent Statements and Reports” may include:

  • Manipulation of material/documents to hide fraud
  • Falsification of material to accomplish a fraud (e.g. to cause unjustified financial rewards, such as a bonus based on falsified financial performance results)

Attendance – Time – Hours

  • Not providing required justification in support of a leave request
  • Failure to submit a leave request
  • Providing false information to receive remuneration for time not worked (e.g. overtime form, leave request, medical note)
  • Unauthorized absence from work
  • Not monitoring employee attendance and leave in accordance with established policies and procedures
  • Submitting overtime not worked
  • Arriving late, excessive breaks, leaving early without notifying your immediate supervisor or manager in a timely manner

Falsification of Documentation

  • Improper use of contracting or purchasing authority
  • Falsifying a travel claim
  • Conspiring to produce a report that reflects an agreed upon version of events (not actual first-hand experience)
  • Obstruction or altering evidence/CBSA information
  • Producing reported results that are not validated or accurate
  • Falsification of experience/education on a job application
  • Providing inflated recommendations

_items.title: Corruption
_items.body:
Dishonest or unethical conduct (bribery, facilitation, conflict of interest) by a person entrusted with a position of authority, often to acquire personal benefit.

  • Facilitation
  • Conflict of Interest

Facilitation

  • Coordinating or assisting in the trafficking of humans and illegal commodities (through an act of commission or omission)
  • Attempting to smuggle any person, good, currency or monetary instrument
  • Allowing yourself to be persuaded or influenced by individuals who are engaging in criminal activities

Conflict of Interest

  • Use of CBSA electronic network or system database to participate in or conduct unlawful or criminal activity
  • Intentionally failing to exercise a delegated authority
  • Intentionally failing to make a proper declaration when crossing at a port of entry
  • Receiving bribes/kick-backs
  • Any behaviour or conduct not limited to the one listed above that is against the CBSA Code of Conduct, the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector and the Policy on Conflict of Interest
  • Failure to report to your immediate supervisor or manager any real, apparent or potential conflicts of interest in a timely manner
  • Failure to report in writing any real, apparent or potential conflicts of interest in a timely manner every time a major change occurs in your personal affairs or official duties
  • Failure to report all outside activities, assets and interests that might give rise to a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest in relation to your official duties

title: Who and Why?
body:
Learning Objectives

This course will enable participants to:

  • Detect and explain an Insider Threat.
  • Identify the different types of internal fraud that can occur.
  • Employ mitigating strategies to minimize the risk of an Insider Threat.
  • Report any suspicion, knowledge or information on an Insider Threat.

title: Risk factors
body:
On top of personality and motivations, risk factors also play an important role in shaping an Insider Threat.

Studies have shown that three critical factors normally have to exist before a previously trustworthy and loyal employee becomes an Insider Threat.
instruction: Select each image to learn more.

_items.title: 1. Personal, financial, or career crisis
_items.body: A personal, financial, or career crisis often precedes or triggers espionage. The individual is placed under great stress as a result of the crisis. This can be: divorce, bankruptcy, unfounded allegations or even criminal convictions.

_items.title: 2. Failure to recognize the signs
_items.body: Friends, co-workers and supervisors fail to recognize or ignore the signs of a serious problem. Friends/colleagues may recognize the issue, but no one acts upon it

_items.title: 3. Personality traits and behaviours
_items.body: The existence of Predisposing Personality Traits/Behaviours.

title: Delisle’s inducements
displayTitle: Delisle’s inducements
body: Delisle did not require any recruitment, he walked into the Russian embassy of his own accord looking to sell military intelligence for “little more than beer money”.
instruction: Select each image below to reveal additional information.

back.title: Financial gain
back.body: Jeffrey Delisle sold secrets to the Russians on the 10th day of every month for nearly five years. Although not considered substantial in the world of espionage, he was paid $3,000 a month and was told not to be too “flashy” with his money.

back.title: Threats
back.body: In 2009, Delisle told the Russians he wanted to stop sharing information. In response, the GRU issued veiled threats to keep him working including sending him a photo of his daughter walking to school.

title: How is fraud detected?
body:
The primary methods used to detect and mitigate fraud are:

  • Data monitoring
  • Audit
  • Reporting
instruction: Select each box to learn more about each method:

back.title: Data Monitoring
back.body:
Monitoring of systems of internal control.

Monitoring and audit of controlled assets.

Monitoring sensitive database use and user activity on CBSA systems.

back.title: Audit
back.body:
Uncovering of system/program gaps and weaknesses related to fraud via:

  • Internal Audit and Evaluation
  • External Audit and Evaluation

back.title: Reporting
back.body:
Based on indicators of fraud (misconduct) that can be observed (and subsequently reported on) by all CBSA employees.

Reporting is especially important for employees, and we will be focusing on the role of reporting more in-depth.

title: Obligation to Report
body: You have an obligation to report the situation immediately.

title: Delisle’s risk factors
displayTitle: Delisle’s risk factors
body:
From the timeline, it is evident that similarly to other Insider Threats, Delisle experienced personal, financial, and career crises; any of which that act as risk factors preceding or triggering an Insider Threat:

Were there other factors that contributed to his ultimate act of “career suicide” such as an absence of intervention or mitigation by his co-workers or managers?

By all accounts, Delisle had a very close relationship with his children but did not appear to have any close friends or colleagues. No one seemed to notice his crises and no one intervened to assist him. 

Jeffrey Delisle was an avid video gamer. He was known to order video game credits that would let him enhance his character with added powers and abilities; abilities he felt were lacking in his real life. 

This highlights specific personality traits and also the extent to which his personal crisis was affecting him.

back.title: The personal crises
back.body: The accident that injured his daughter, the concerns that his wife was having an extra-marital affair.

back.title: The career crises
back.body: His inability to sail due to diabetes which severely limited his naval career.

title: Assessment of Knowledge
body: Now that you've covered all modules, let's take a few moments to check what you've learned on the overall course. Take the time to read the scenario and answer the related questions below. Keep in mind that marks are not assigned to the questions and the questions are not timed.

title: The threat from within
body:
Watch this clip from the movie Betrayed to understand how the most serious threat to organizations often don’t come from the outside, but from within.

A link to the full video has been placed in the learning resources section in the course menu, in case you want to watch it.

00:00:11,311 -- 00:00:16,850 : A Production of the FBI
00:00:21,855 -- 00:00:28,428: In Association with:
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
Office of the National Counterintelligence Executive
00:00:44,557 -- 00:00:46,913: I got it.
00:00:46,913 -- 00:00:50,350: Are you prepared to move it?
00:00:50,774 -- 00:00:53,820: Yes
00:00:54,350 -- 00:00:56,790: Can you move it now?
00:00:56,790 -- 00:00:57,790: Yes
00:01:03,192 -- 00:01:07,834: I can meet you this morning, calling you now.
00:01:14,074 -- 00:01:18,144: So uh, what's the chance you'll be wearing that outfit this morning when I see ya?
00:01:18,745 -- 00:01:20,980: Not good, but maybe tonight.
00:01:22,082 -- 00:01:23,450: Okay, you got a deal.
00:01:52,679 -- 00:01:56,382: C.P. Alpha One, subject departing heading north on Oak.
00:02:02,188 -- 00:02:05,291: C.P. Charlie One subject heading south on 3rd.
00:02:07,026 -- 00:02:10,363: Hey it's me. I'm going to stop for coffee, do you want anything?
00:02:10,997 -- 00:02:12,398: Yes, my regular. 
00:02:13,233 -- 00:02:13,800: Grande.
00:02:14,601 -- 00:02:15,268: Always.
00:02:15,268 -- 00:02:15,902: You got it.
00:02:16,769 -- 00:02:18,605: This is C.P. contact me.
00:02:19,405 -- 00:02:20,173: Meeting as planned.
00:02:21,274 -- 00:02:25,011: Please remind everyone he's got a permit to carry,  but we can't confirm he's armed.
00:02:37,624 -- 00:02:41,027: C.P. Charlie Two, subject turning west onto Water.
00:03:27,013 -- 00:03:28,013: Here.
00:03:29,309 -- 00:03:30,076: Thank you.
00:03:32,345 -- 00:03:34,814: That, that's going to be the last one for a while.
00:03:37,550 -- 00:03:38,918: Am I going to see you tonight?
00:03:38,918 -- 00:03:40,253: Ya, absolute...
00:03:42,222 -- 00:03:43,223: FBI let me see your hands!
00:03:43,223 -- 00:03:44,691: FBI Hands! Hands!
00:03:44,691 -- 00:03:47,927: Drop the cup! Drop the cup! Drop the cup!
00:03:50,330 -- 00:03:52,398: Drop the cup ma'am! Drop the Cup!
00:03:55,746 -- 00:04:00,206: Turn around. Put your hands on your head! Hands on your head.
00:04:00,573 -- 00:04:01,407: Turn around!
00:04:01,874 -- 00:04:03,243: Put your hands behind your back.

title: What is internal fraud?
body:
What is Employee Misconduct?

Misconduct includes:

  • Any action or inaction by an employee that is contrary to established policy, standards, procedures or practices of the CBSA.
  • Violations of legislation for which criminal sanctions are applicable.
  • Violations of other laws, rules and regulations administered by the CBSA.
  • Any other act which would bring the CBSA into disrepute or effect the Agency’s working relationship with other law enforcement partners.

Internal fraud represents an intentional act that is committed by an employee to secure an unfair or unlawful gain as well as the deliberate violation of laws, regulations, and policies (even when the benefit is non-financial in nature).

    Fraud is considered a type of employee misconduct.

    By engaging in this type of misconduct, associating with inappropriate contacts, or not properly safeguarding the physical/informational assets of the organization – you are making yourself susceptible to becoming an Insider Threat.

title: Question 1
body: Identify the three different methods for detecting fraudulent activity of Insider Threats
instruction: Match the definition to the method for detecting fraudulent activity.

_items.text: Uncovering of system/program gaps and weaknesses related to fraud.
Monitoring sensitive database use and user activity on CBSA systems.
Based on indicators of fraud (misconduct) that can be observed (and subsequently reported on) by all CBSA employees.

_feedback.correct:
Correct.

Internal Fraud and Insider Threats can be uncovered/detected in a number of ways.

Data Monitoring

  • Monitoring of systems of internal control
  • Monitoring and audit of controlled assets
  • Monitoring sensitive database use and user activity on CBSA systems

Audit

Uncovering of system/program gaps and weaknesses related to fraud via:

  • Internal Audit and Evaluation
  • External Audit and Evaluation

Reporting

Based on indicators of fraud (misconduct) that can be observed (and subsequently reported on) by all CBSA employees.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

Internal Fraud and Insider Threats can be uncovered/detected in a number of ways.

Data Monitoring

  • Monitoring of systems of internal control
  • Monitoring and audit of controlled assets
  • Monitoring sensitive database use and user activity on CBSA systems

Audit

Uncovering of system/program gaps and weaknesses related to fraud via:

  • Internal Audit and Evaluation
  • External Audit and Evaluation

Reporting

Based on indicators of fraud (misconduct) that can be observed (and subsequently reported on) by all CBSA employees.

title: How to report an Insider Threat?
displayTitle: How to report an Insider Threat?
body: Imagine that you notice a co-worker is demonstrating some of the behaviours of an Insider Threat. Would you know who or where to go to report it?
instruction: Select the box to view the details on where to report an Insider Threat.

_items.title: Where to report an Insider Threat.
_items.body:
Insider Threats and fraudulent acts are considered to be types of employee misconduct. Under the CBSA Code of Conduct, CBSA employees must promptly report any allegation, suspicion, or information concerning employee misconduct to their:

  • Immediate supervisor or manager; or
  • Director (if the circumstances warrant it).

Employees can also report an allegation of misconduct by sending an encrypted email to CBSA-ASFC_Professional_Integrity-Intégrité_Professionnelle (CBSA-ASFC_Professional_Integrity-Integrite_Professionnelle@cbsa-asfc.gc.ca).

The email should include: the names and position titles of all individuals involved and a summary of the allegation.

The Security and Professional Standards Analysis (SPSA) Section, Personnel Security and Professional Standards Division (PSPSD), will follow-up to gather additional information if needed.

Management and employees can also contact the Manager of the SPSA Section at 343-291-6141, or the Director of the PSPSD at 343-291-6345, to discuss an issue and to obtain guidance.

title: Personality Traits
body:
Studies have shown that individuals who have been considered an Insider Threat possess specific personality traits and behaviours.

  • Narcisisstic Traits
  • Anti-Social Traits
instruction: Select each box to learn more about the behaviours associated with each personality.

back.title: Narcissistic Traits
back.body:
Someone may display narcissistic traits such as:

  • Inflated sense of self-worth.
  • Seeks immediate gratification.
  • Resents authority.
  • Arrogant, angry and hostile.
  • Intolerant to criticism, inability to accept responsibility.
  • Appears self-centered, entitled and undervalued.
  • Reacts in a rebellious, passive-aggressive or destructive manner if their needs are not met.
  • Feels the organization is unresponsive to their needs.

back.title: Anti-Social Traits
back.body:
Someone may display anti-social traits such as:

  • Tends to reject the normal rules of society.
  • Seems manipulative or self-serving.
  • Lacks in guilt or remorse when they do something wrong.
